content: The "Entrepreneurial Investment Act of 1996" allows smaller bank holding companies to make equity capital investments. The Bank Holding Company Act of 1956 is amended to allow bank holding companies to acquire shares of companies engaged in unauthorized activities, with certain conditions. The Bank Holding Company Act of 1956 is amended to allow bank holding companies to acquire shares of companies engaged in unauthorized activities, with conditions such as total consolidated assets less than $1 billion, significant debt relationship for at least 1 year, investments not exceeding 50% of excess capital, and shares not representing 25%. The Bank Holding Company Act of 1956 amendment allows bank holding companies to acquire shares of companies with conditions, including total assets less than $1 billion, significant debt relationship for 1 year, investments not exceeding 50% of excess capital, shares not representing 25%, and restrictions on joint marketing by depository institutions. The Bank Holding Company Act of 1956 amendment allows bank holding companies to acquire shares of companies with conditions, including restrictions on joint marketing by depository institutions. Prior approval from the Board is required for investment activities, and accounting requirements include obtaining approval for investments under certain conditions. The Bank Holding Company Act of 1956 amendment allows bank holding companies to acquire shares of companies with conditions, including restrictions on joint marketing by depository institutions. Investments made under this paragraph are valued quarterly based on the lower of the initial cost or book value of the shares. Compliance with limitations is determined by marking shares to market value. The Bank Holding Company Act of 1956 amendment allows bank holding companies to acquire shares of companies with conditions, including restrictions on joint marketing by depository institutions. The value of shares acquired is determined by the lower of the cost at acquisition or the book value of the shares. Acquisition of shares in excess of limitations through debt satisfaction is not subject to restrictions. The Bank Holding Company Act of 1956 amendment allows bank holding companies to acquire shares of companies with conditions, including restrictions on joint marketing by depository institutions. Shares acquired in satisfaction of debt contracted in good faith are exempt from limitations and must be divested within a 3-year period. The Board has the authority to supervise and regulate investments in voting shares of companies and can require divestiture of shares if necessary to preserve safety and soundness. The Board has the authority to supervise and regulate investments in shares to maintain the safety and soundness of insured depository institutions, including taking action to sell shares if capital levels fall below a certain threshold. Definitions are provided for clarity. The Board has the authority to supervise and regulate investments in shares to maintain the safety and soundness of insured depository institutions. Definitions for terms like excess capital and book value of shares are provided for clarity. The Board has the authority to supervise and regulate investments in shares to maintain the safety and soundness of insured depository institutions. The term 'depository institution' includes a foreign bank for purposes of ownership percentage calculations.
